title: How to Spot a Bad Ghost Tour
content:
Not all ghost tours are created equal. After years of traveling and investigating, I can say this plainly: the worst ghost tours aren't just boring—they actively damage the experience of a city. I've taken tours that felt rushed, poorly researched, and more focused on theatrics than truth. The good news is that most bad ghost tours leave warning signs long before you book.

What are the warning signs of a bad ghost tour?

Bad ghost tours usually reveal themselves through vagueness. If a tour description relies heavily on phrases like "dark secrets," "unspeakable horrors," or "guaranteed activity" without explaining where you'll go or what you'll learn, that's a red flag. Overpromising is another common issue. Legitimate guides describe history and reported experiences. Bad tours promise proof, certainty, or fear—things no ethical guide can guarantee. Skeptics especially should avoid tours that guarantee paranormal encounters.

How do you evaluate ghost tour reviews?

Volume and consistency matter more than isolated praise. A handful of glowing reviews mixed with frequent complaints about pacing, accuracy, or group size should give you pause. I pay close attention to reviews that mention guide knowledge, storytelling clarity, and how questions were handled. Complaints about misinformation or rushed stops often signal deeper quality issues.

What should tour descriptions include?

Strong tour descriptions explain the route, duration, group size, and general tone. They tell you whether the tour is history-focused, theatrical, family-friendly, or adult-oriented. When descriptions avoid specifics—no locations, no structure, no expectations—it usually means the tour itself lacks structure as well. Understanding what different tour formats offer helps you spot when descriptions don't match reality.

Red flags by tour type

Different tour formats have different warning signs:
  • Walking tours – Watch for routes that seem too short or groups over 30 people
  • Investigation tours – Be wary of guaranteed evidence or "portal opening" claims
  • Pub crawls – Avoid tours that prioritize drinking over storytelling
  • Cemetery tours – Poor tours often disrespect the sites or lack historical depth

How do you verify guide quality?

Guide quality shows up indirectly. Look for mentions of background, training, or long-term experience rather than dramatic personas. In my experience, the best guides don't position themselves as paranormal celebrities. They present themselves as storytellers, historians, or investigators who encourage questions rather than shutting them down.

What group size is too large?

Large groups dilute everything—audio clarity, pacing, and atmosphere. Once groups climb past 25 people, tours often become crowd management exercises instead of storytelling experiences. Smaller groups allow guides to adapt, answer questions, and slow down when a location deserves more attention. If group size concerns you, private tours offer more control.

Questions to ask before booking

Good tour companies answer these questions clearly:
  • How many stops are included?
  • What's the maximum group size?
  • Is the tour family-friendly or adults-only?
  • What happens in bad weather?
  • How experienced is the guide?
If a company can't or won't answer, look elsewhere.

How do you find good tours instead?

The safest approach is to prioritize clarity over hype. Look for tours with detailed descriptions, consistent reviews, and realistic language about what participants will experience. Cities with strong ghost tour traditions—New Orleans, Savannah, Edinburgh—have multiple quality options. Competition raises standards.

What to do if you end up on a bad tour

If you realize early that a tour isn't meeting expectations:
  • Ask questions to see if the guide can provide depth
  • Check if you can get a refund through the booking platform
  • Leave an honest review to help future travelers
  • Consider exploring independently afterward—see our guided vs self-guided comparison

Practical Takeaway

A bad ghost tour rarely fails quietly—it leaves clues. Vague descriptions, exaggerated promises, oversized groups, and dismissive guides are all signs to walk away. If a tour respects history, sets clear expectations, and values questions over spectacle, it's usually worth your time.
